Award.AwardTitle: Classical and Quantum Aspects of Black Holes, Horizons and Asymptotic Symmetries
Award.AbstractNarration:
The visible universe has edges, known as event horizons, which surround a black hole or a region of the universe speeding away faster than light. The nature of these edges has vexed physicists, beginning with Einstein, for nearly a century. They are governed by an elegant and beautiful set of quantum laws discovered four decades ago by Bekenstein and Hawking. These laws indicate that black holes are at once the simplest and most complex objects in the physical universe. They are simple because, according to Einstein's general relativity there is in effect nothing inside - space ends at the horizon. They are complex because the Bekenstein-Hawking laws imply that they must carry the maximal allowable information. The coexistence of these dichotomous descriptions of black holes underlies a deep paradox whose resolution is a focal point of modern physics. While the basic paradox remains unsolved, much has been learned using a variety of apporaches. Resolving the paradox is a central problem in modern physics and will likely lead to profound new insights into the nature of our universe, comparable to those following from quantum mechanics and relativity.

In this project we propose specific steps to continue these fruitful investigations as well as more generally address universal aspects of the paradox, in its many manifestations surrounding black hole and other horizons. Our investigations will be informed by important lessons learned in the process of studying string theory (a candidate for a fundamental unified theory of nature), but we will concentrate on universal aspects of large-scale observable phenomena which are independent of any assumptions about the as yet-unknown completion of the fundamental laws of nature. Here we pursue a bottom-up approach working from astrophysically observed properties of horizons, the powerful symmetry -general covariance- underlying Einstein's theory of general relativity, and basic physical and mathematical consistency.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project we discovered some important long-overlooked properties of spacetime implied by, but hidden within the Einstein equation for the gravitational force. These have far-reaching consequences for a number of issues in gravitational physics which we have started and will continue to explore. These discoveries followed from the mathematical equivalence [1] we proved of two famous results in disparate fields from over half century ago: Weinberg's so called soft-graviton theorem [2], which he derived using quantum field theory and the asymptotic symmetries [3] of Bondi, van der Burg, Metzner and Sachs. These are further equivalent to the gravitational memory effect [4], which might be measurable in upcoming gravity wave experiments.

One of the newly-understood properties is that the empty space vacuum is not as empty as it seems [5]. In fact, there is an infinite number of vacua which differ subtly at its boundaries and carry distinguishing features which we referred to as soft hair.

In the last year we looked specifically at how this affects the structure of black holes and the famous no-hair theorem [6], which states that black holes are featureless bald objects characterized only by their mass, charge and spin. We found, in contrast, that soft hair appears at the boundary of empty space where it meets the horizon of a black hole [7]. Mathematically, the no hair theorem is correct but it had been physically misinterpreted. This discovery invalidated Hawking’s famous 1975 argument [8] that black holes destroy information because it assumed the no-hair theorem in its misinterpreted form. Moreover, it suggests a new line of research into the infamous black hole information paradox - one of the great paradoxes of twentieth century physics - which we pursued over the last year from several perspectives [7, 9].

In a separate research direction, we are applying our knowledge of symmetries of rapidly spinning black holes to make analytic predictions for observations at the Event Horizon Telescope (EHT) or other astronomical observatories. In the last year we found analytic solutions for the photon trajectories which arrive at the telescope from the region very near the black holes [10] and derived the universal behavior of the magnetospheres [11]. This complements numerical analyses by the EHT team in revealing a qualitative signal behavior which would be nearly impossible to find with computer simulations.
